title: Charlie Kirk vigil draws thousands to Boston Common, ends suddenly due to safety concerns, organizer says
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Local News "That's exactly why we needed to do it, because you can't speak your mind in Massachusetts without fear of being hurt.
" Pamela Blyakhman of Revere, left, and Sharon Tamagna of Merrimack during a vigil in support of slain far-right activist Charlie Kirk at Boston Common on Thursday, September 18, 2025.
Ken McGagh for The Boston Globe ShareSend this article to your social connections.

title: Can Bruins’ Morgan Geekie prove that his 33-goal season wasn’t an outlier?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Boston Bruins "I felt like I hit rock bottom pretty early, at least mentally, and and got stuck there.
" Morgan Geekie is expected to be one of the key cogs up front for Boston this season.

Ken McGagh for The Boston Globe By Conor Ryan September 18, 2025 3 minutes to read A candid Morgan Geekie didn’t mince words on Thursday when asked about the sizable expectations placed on his shoulders this season.

title: Video: 2 humpback whales breach right next to N.H. fishermen
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Local News “Dude, dude, this isn’t good.
” Two mariners on Tuesday nearly had their boat capsized by a breaching humpback whale.
Dale Sprague Two fishermen had an unexpected close call with two humpback whales while fishing off the coast of New Hampshire on Tuesday, an encounter that was captured on video.

title: Aaron Rodgers recalls ‘1 of the greatest plays’ he’s seen playing Patriots at Gillette Stadium
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: New England Patriots "There may have been a few of us on the sideline who had a very tiny, quiet 'go' on that play.
" Aaron Rodgers is 0-2 in games started at Gillette Stadium.
Jim Davis/The Boston Globe By Conor Ryan September 18, 2025 2 minutes to read Gillette Stadium has served as a house of horrors for Aaron Rodgers and the Steelers over the years.

title: Cambridge Animal Commission warns residents about ‘toy poodle’ extortion scam
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Local News The scam claims that the puppies are 8 weeks old and fully vaccinated with all documentation, but there aren’t actually any puppies for sale.
An extortion scam is claiming that 8-week-old toy poodles are for sale in Cambridge.
Cambridge Animal Commission The Cambridge Animal Commission is alerting the public to an extortion scam claiming to offer toy poodle puppies for sale.

title: What Alex Cora said in latest update about Roman Anthony’s return from injury
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Boston Red Sox "It’s going to take a while.
He’s doing everything possible to hopefully get back.
” Roman Anthony's absence has hindered Boston's playoff hopes down the stretch.

title: Nantucket seagull apparently smashes car window with clam
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Local News This seagull is no stranger to criminal activity, committing the equally “fowl” offense of stealing a man’s wallet last year.
There’s a menace on the loose in Nantucket, smashing car windshields and mugging unsuspecting civilians.
Also, it has wings.

title: Worcester man convicted of kidnapping and strangling girl, then throwing her off a bridge
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Crime “I feel like I’m living in 'To Kill a Mockingbird,'” the man’s attorney told Boston.
com after he was found guilty.
Joshua Hubert of Worcester was found guilty of attempted murder, strangulation, and kidnapping but was acquitted of rape, court records showed.

title: Mattapan man found guilty of murder in 2020 shooting
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Local News Jason Woods, 32, was found guilty in the fatal shooting of 26-year-old Lovenson Pierre in 2020.

By Sana Muneer September 18, 2025 | 7:29 PM Less than a minute to read A Mattapan man was convicted Thursday of second-degree murder in a 2020 shooting that killed a 26-year-old Quincy resident, prosecutors announced.
Jason Woods, 32, was found guilty in the 2020 fatal shooting of 26-year-old Lovenson Pierre, of Quincy, the office of Suffolk County District Attorney Kevin Hayden said in a press release.

title: Lowell man convicted of stealing gold chain from man fatally struck by MBTA trolley
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Local News Christopher Polanco, 26, will serve six months in the House of Correction, followed by six months probation, officials said.

By Sana Muneer September 18, 2025 | 6:32 PM 1 minute to read A Lowell man was sentenced to six months in jail after stealing a gold chain off a man who was struck and killed by a MBTA trolley in 2023, prosecutors announced Thursday.

Christopher Polanco, 26, was convicted Monday of one count of larceny under $1,200, the office of Suffolk County District Attorney Kevin Hayden said in a press releasePolanco was sentenced to one year in the House of Correction, followed by six months probation, officials said.
